subject: Re: [junit] JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: ... Code has two effects; it returns a result to the caller or it changes state somewhere else. If you want to test code that doesn t return to the caller,
messageBody:
javainsel wrote:

> It seems that with JUnit I can only test methods which return a
> value. Using JUnit will change the code one would normally create:
> Because of JUnit you need to overwrite equals(), toString() and are
> not allowed to use void return type if you want to test that method.

Code has two effects; it returns a result to the caller or it
changes state somewhere else. If you want to test code that doesn't
return to the caller, look for the where the changes are made and
inspect them to see if they're what you'd expect - this can be
easier or harder than it sounds depending on how the code is organized.

Bill de hÓra
